examples.en: No matter how many times I threw the darts, they wouldn't hit the dartboard, and in the end, they were all misses.
examples.ja: 何回矢を投げてもダーツボードに当たらなくて、結局全部外れだったよ。

examples.en: The teacher's prediction was completely off the mark.
examples.ja: 先生の予想は完全に外れでした。

examples.en: The man lived in a small house on the forest's periphery.
examples.ja: 男は森の外れの小さな家に住んでいた。

examples.en: The princess was wearing a dress that doesn't suit the season.
examples.ja: 王女は、季節外れのドレスを着ていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
外れる is "to come off" or "to be off." And this is its noun form — <vocabulary>a miss</vocabulary>, aka something that's <vocabulary>off the mark</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, it's completely off the original goal or intended target.

This word refers to something that falls outside of what's expected, central, or correct. Like something that didn't match your hopes or expectations — a losing lottery ticket or a disappointing purchase. It can also describe a place on the <vocabulary>periphery</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>outskirts</vocabulary> — since you're "off the mark" from somewhere more central.
reading_mnemonic: You shoot, but it's <vocabulary>a miss</vocabulary>. Way <vocabulary>off the mark</vocabulary>. Better put on your <reading>haz</reading>mat (はず) suit because you hit a toxic waste barrel instead of the target. Put your hazmat suits on, everyone!

examples.en: There are all kinds of people in the world.
examples.ja: 世の中には、色々な人がいます。

examples.en: That is the rule of society.
examples.ja: それが世の中のルールだ。

examples.en: Could we say that this world is safe?
examples.ja: この世の中は、安全だと言えるのでしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>world</kanji> is the <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it <vocabulary>the world</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.

examples.en: I prayed for the hurricane victims.
examples.ja: ハリケーンのひがい者のために祈りました。

examples.en: I pray that you will pass the national examinations successfully.
examples.ja: 国家試験に無事合格できるように祈っています。

examples.en: I don’t think many Japanese people know Japan’s national sport "sumo" used to be a ritual to pray for a bountiful rice harvest.
examples.ja: 日本の国技である相撲が、かつては米の豊作を祈る儀式だったことを知ってる日本人がたくさんいるとは思えないな。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pray</kanji> and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to pray for</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You gotta pray for Christmas presents if you want Santa to bring you some!" "<reading>I know</reading> (いの), I know," you reply as you begin to pray for presents. You should say this out loud to remember it better.

examples.en: A safety prayer charm was hanging from the car's rearview mirror.
examples.ja: 車のバックミラーに、安全祈願のお守りがぶら下がっていた。

examples.en: I went to a shrine to pray that I could get my visa without any trouble.
examples.ja: 無事にビザが取れるよう、神社でご祈願してきました。

examples.en: You can offer a prayer at either a shrine or a temple.
examples.ja: ご祈願は、神社でもお寺でもできますよ。

examples.en: Koichi can do the war dance of the Martians.
examples.ja: コウイチは、火星人の戦勝祈願のおどりをおどることができます。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>pray</kanji> and make a <kanji>request</kanji>, as a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary> to some deity at a shrine or temple. 

This usually refers to making a wish or asking for a favor from a deity, like prosperity, good health, or winning an important sports game.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I heard that person just gave birth to a baby last winter and that she'll have another one this fall.
examples.ja: あの人、去年の冬に赤ちゃんを産んだばかりなのに今年の秋にもまた赤ちゃんを産むんですって。

examples.en: A lot of baby mantises came out of the egg that the mantis laid.
examples.ja: カマキリが産んだたまごの中からたくさんの赤ちゃんカマキリが出てきました。

examples.en: Okay. You ready to push again? You are going to have twins! Okay, okay, come on, you can do it. You can do it!
examples.ja: よし、もう一度いきむ準備はいいかい？君は双子の赤ちゃんを産むんだよ！ 大丈夫、大丈夫。頑張れ！君ならできるよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>give birth</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to give birth</vocabulary>.

You know another 産む as well (生む). This 産む is more sciency, but both are good to know.
reading_mnemonic: You know another "to give birth" word (生む). Guess what!? They share readings!

examples.en: That boy was whistling happily.
examples.ja: その男の子は、うれしそうに口笛をふいていました。

examples.en: I frequently hear the sound of my boss practicing his whistling when I'm at the office late at night.
examples.ja: 夜おそくまでオフィスにいると、よく上司が口笛の練習をしている音が聞こえてくる。

examples.en: My dog doesn’t come to my whistle because I’m bad at whistling.
examples.ja: 口笛が下手くそなので、私が口笛を吹いても犬が来てくれません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>flute</kanji>... Normal flutes you blow air through to make a sound. How do you blow air through your mouth to make a sound? By <vocabulary>whistling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings put together. Thank 口 for being a body part, which tends to cause this to happen. So, you have 口 (くち) and 笛 (ふえ) put together, though ふえ changes to ぶえ, maybe because you can't whistle properly? Buuuweeee. Buwwweee.

examples.en: I participated in a seminar as a jazz critic.
examples.ja: ジャズ評論家として、とあるセミナーに参加してきました。

examples.en: Participating in club activities is optional.
examples.ja: クラブ活動に参加するかどうかは、任意です。

examples.en: I’m participating in the skyscraper observation tour this Sunday.
examples.ja: 今週の日曜日、摩天楼の見学ツアーに参加します。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 参加 is <kanji>participation</kanji>? Well, make that a verb with する and you have yourself <vocabulary>to participate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the reading of 参加.

examples.en: Surprisingly, the oldest participant of the moviegoer party was 100 years old.
examples.ja: 映画好きのパーティーの最年長参加者は、なんと百才だった。

examples.en: Thanks to one participant, the meeting was thrown into chaos. It was a disaster.
examples.ja: ある参加者が会議を混乱させてしまってね。さんざんだったよ。

examples.en: Koichi's speech received genuine praise from the participants.
examples.ja: コウイチのスピーチは、参加者達から心からの称賛を受けました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 参加 is <kanji>participation</kanji>, so <kanji>someone</kanji> who does participation is a <vocabulary>participant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That police officer always says one word too many.
examples.ja: あの警察官はいつも余計な一言が多い。

examples.en: That policeman escaped in the confusion!
examples.ja: あの警察官、混乱にまぎれてバックレやがったぞ！

examples.en: When the police officer found the suspect, he was painting a beautiful landscape on a hilltop.
examples.ja: 警察官が容疑者を発見した際、男は丘の上で美しい風景画を描いていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>police</kanji> (警察) <kanji>government</kanji> is full of <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>s. This is the formal way to say "police officer." It is similar to 警官, but has a slightly more official feel to it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Don't you realize that such comments disturb everyone's harmony?
examples.ja: そういう発言がみんなの和を乱しているってこと、気づいてないの？

examples.en: Many kids with ADHD don't like having the rhythm of their lives thrown out of order.
examples.ja: ADHDの子どもは、生活のリズムを乱されることをイヤがる子が多いです。

examples.en: I ran with my hair in disarray, but in the end I didn't make my scheduled flight.
examples.ja: 髪を乱して走ったが、結局予定の飛行機には間に合わなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 乱れる is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going <vocabulary>to put in disorder</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to throw out of order</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disturb</vocabulary> whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for your actions.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 乱れる, so hopefully you know it already.

examples.en: When I was told not to be friends with aliens, it made me want to do it even more.
examples.ja: 宇宙人と友達になってはいけないと言われて、余計になりたくなった。

examples.en: To put it simply, we're aliens too, aren't we?
examples.ja: 平たく言えば、私達も宇宙人だよね。

examples.en: Koichi’s photographs honestly and sympathetically portray aliens who were victims of drought and the Great Depression on Mars.
examples.ja: コウイチの写真は、火星で干ばつと大恐慌の犠牲となった宇宙人たちを正直に、かつ同情を込めてとらえている。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 宇宙 is <kanji>space</kanji>? Well, a <kanji>person</kanji> from space is an <vocabulary>alien</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help to know how to read the word 宇宙 on its own, too.

examples.en: The enemy's sudden attack threw the space shuttle into chaos.
examples.ja: 敵からのいきなりのアタックで、宇宙船は大混乱となった。

examples.en: Rigid rules have been established to live in this spaceship.
examples.ja: この宇宙船での生活には、きびしいルールが設けられています。

examples.en: Nearly all of the sixteen space ships were retained and refurbished.
examples.ja: 十六台の宇宙船のほとんど全てが、保持され改装されました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 宇宙 is <kanji>outer space</kanji> and how 船 is <kanji>ship</kanji>, right? Well, put those together and you have an outer space ship (better known as a <vocabulary>space ship</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 宇宙 beforehand as well.

examples.en: Amazon sent me two more pairs of shoes than I ordered.
examples.ja: アマゾンから、注文より二足余計に履き物が送られてきました。

examples.en: When you write "Please take shoes off here" and "Please take kimonos off here" in hiragana, they look exactly the same.
examples.ja: 「ここで履き物をぬいでください」と「ここでは着物をぬいでください」を平仮名で書くと全く同じになる。

examples.en: In Japanese, indoor footwear is called "uwabaki" and outdoor footwear is called "sotobaki."
examples.ja: 日本語で、屋内の履き物は「上履き」、屋外の履き物は「外履き」と呼ばれます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 履く is "to put on shoes" and 物 means "thing"? Well, combine them and you have a word for things you put on your feet, a.k.a. <vocabulary>footwear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>shoes</vocabulary>.

You might know that 履く is used for lots of different clothes you wear below the waist, but be careful: <vocabulary>履き物</vocabulary> only refers to footwear and shoes.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is that of 履く and 物 put together. Just know those separately and you should be able to figure this one out as well.

examples.en: In order to become a rock musician, I need to persuade my dad.
examples.ja: ロックミュージシャンになるには、親父を説得する必要がある。

examples.en: I persuaded my wife not to buy unnecessary things.
examples.ja: 余計な物を買いすぎないよう、妻を説得しました。

examples.en: It wasn't easy to convince my brother to bail out of the bacon-trafficking business.
examples.ja: ベーコンの密売ビジネスから足を洗うよう兄を説得するのは、容易なことではなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 説得 is <kanji>persuasion</kanji>, so what is the verb version of that? <vocabulary>To persuade</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also immensely help to know the reading of the word 説得.

examples.en: Many users got confused when WaniKani's subscription fee decreased.
examples.ja: ユーザーの多くは、ワニカニのサブスクリプションが安くなったことに混乱した。

examples.en: During the Great East Japanese Earthquake, people around Tokyo didn't panic, they just did what they could.
examples.ja: 東日本大震災では、東京周辺の人々は混乱することもなく、ただ自分にできることをしていた。

examples.en: You’ll probably get confused, but my brother is striving to overcome his fear of death right now, so please leave him alone.
examples.ja: 君はおそらく混乱すると思うけど、弟は今、死への恐怖を克服しようと必死で努力しているところなの。だから、そっとしておいてあげてくれないかな？

meaning_mnemonic: If 混乱 is <kanji>confusion</kanji> then making it into a verb would cause it <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 混乱 so no reason for you <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>, right?

examples.en: I had my teacher decrease the number of homework assignments I was given.
examples.ja: 先生に宿題をちょっとだけ減らしてもらいました。

examples.en: I asked them to reduce the amount of cream, but they didn't accept my request.
examples.ja: クリームの量を減らすようお願いしたんですが、聞き入れてもらえませんでした。

examples.en: The plague reduced the number of blowfish to half its previous level.
examples.ja: その疫病は、河豚の数をそれまでの水準の半分に減らした。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decrease</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decrease something</vocabulary>. You can differentiate this from 減る because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The <reading>rush</reading> (らす) of decreasing something fills your veins.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 減る, so if you know that reading you should know this one.

examples.en: I will continue WaniKani forever ♡
examples.ja: これからもずっとワニカニを続けるつもりです♡

examples.en: Why do you all keep criticizing me?
examples.ja: どうしてあなた達は私のことを批判し続けるのですか？

examples.en: Weekends are awesome because I can continue to sleep all day long.
examples.ja: 一日中寝続けられるので、週末は最高だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>continue</kanji>, so 続ける means <vocabulary>to continue something</vocabulary>. It's a transitive verb, so it takes a direct object. You can 続ける your work, for example, and you should 続ける your WaniKani lessons at a pace that works for you!

Although it has the same 続 kanji, this word is a bit different from 続く, which is used for when something just continues on its own (like rain, or trends). It can be hard to remember the difference, so here's a mnemonic to help you with 続ける:

You only <reading>care</reading> (ける) about things that you can continue through your own actions. For those other things that just continue on their own, you're like, That's <reading>coo</reading>' (く), but you’re not that interested.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 続く, so be sure to know that so you can know this.

examples.en: You can’t use proper nouns in the game Shiritori.
examples.ja: しりとりに固有名詞は使えません。

examples.en: How are proper nouns different from nouns?
examples.ja: 固有名詞と名詞はどうちがいますか。

examples.en: I eagerly looked up a word that I didn't recognize in the dictionary, but couldn't find it and it turned out it was just a proper noun.
examples.ja: 分からない単語を辞書で一生懸命探してたんだけど、見つからないと思ったら、固有名詞だった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>noun</kanji> (名詞) that <kanji>has</kanji> <kanji>hard</kanji>ness is a noun that can't be budged. It's a big noun, so big that you have to capitalize these kinds of nouns in English. It is a <vocabulary>proper noun</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 名詞 as well.

examples.en: Transitive verbs take objects.
examples.ja: 他動詞は目的語を取ります。

examples.en: Please change all of these transitive verbs into intransitive verbs.
examples.ja: ここに書いてある他動詞を全部自動詞に書きかえてください。

examples.en: Is memorization the only way to learn if the verb is transitive or intransitive?
examples.ja: その動詞が他動詞か自動詞かを学ぶには、まる暗記するしかないのかな。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 動詞 means "verb"? When the verb is done to some <kanji>other</kanji> thing, it's a <vocabulary>transitive verb</vocabulary>.

That means it takes a direct object. Verbs like 食べる, 使う, and 上げる are transitive verbs because they need a direct object, an "other" thing, to receive their action.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Not that you asked me, but I think you should leave the yakuza.
examples.ja: 余計な事を言うようだけど、暴力団から足を洗った方がいいと思うよ。

examples.en: My dad will never approve of my joining a gangster organization.
examples.ja: 父は私が暴力団に入ることを認めてくれないでしょう。

examples.en: What’s the difference between the Yakuza and Kanto Rengo?
examples.ja: 暴力団と関東連合の違いは何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>group</kanji> that has <kanji>power</kanji> using <kanji>violence</kanji>? Sounds like a <vocabulary>crime syndicate</vocabulary> to me, probably the <vocabulary>Yakuza</vocabulary> or some other <vocabulary>gangster organization</vocabulary> .
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The suspect admitted his guilt.
examples.ja: 容疑者は、自分の罪を認めた。

examples.en: The suspect conveyed a message of optimism to the teenagers.
examples.ja: その容疑者は、十代の若者たちにオプティミズムのメッセージを伝えた。

examples.en: Apparently Satoshi is wanted as a suspect in the Sweet Dumpling Poisoning Case.
examples.ja: サトシはみたらし団子毒殺事件の容疑者として指名手配されたらしいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: I have a <kanji>suspicion</kanji> (容疑) about <kanji>someone</kanji>. That someone is my main <vocabulary>suspect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to be able to read 容疑 first, though.

examples.en: The motorcycle gang confessed that they had run over the raccoon.
examples.ja: 暴走族は、アライグマをひいたことを認めた。

examples.en: I will never ever acknowledge your joining of a biker gang.
examples.ja: 暴走族に入るなんて、ゼッタイにゼッタイに認めませんよ。

examples.en: Mr. Viet, I would be grateful if you could reply as soon as possible about your time spent in a biker gang.
examples.ja: ビエトさん、あなたが暴走族をしていた頃のエピソードについて、早急にお返事いただけると幸いです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tribe</kanji> that <kanji>runs wild</kanji> (暴走) is what the Japanese call a <vocabulary>biker gang</vocabulary>. Just imagine them riding around on their bikes, running wild. They're also close, like a family. How nice!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tofugu holds a drinking party every night to help stimulate the economy.
examples.ja: トーフグが毎晩飲み会を設けているのは、経済活性化のためです。

examples.en: My great grandfather told me he had to "economize because he's broke." Apparently "economizing" means being thrifty with your money.
examples.ja: ひいおじいちゃんが、「金欠だから経済しないと」って言ってたけど、なんか経済するって節約するって意味らしいよ。

examples.en: Since Koichi was inaugurated as President, the US economy has continued to recover at a rapid pace.
examples.ja: コウイチが大統領に就任してからというもの、アメリカの経済は急ピッチで回復している。

meaning_mnemonic: When a <kanji>passage of time</kanji> <kanji>comes to an end</kanji>, you look back on it and see how well you did. Did we make more money? Did we make less? That's all <vocabulary>economics</vocabulary>, baby (that's money, baby!).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The さい changes to ざい, though, so watch out for that.

examples.en: That's enough! You've made too many errors in judgement recently.
examples.ja: いい加減にしろ！最近判断ミスが多すぎるぞ。

examples.en: Cut the BS, refs!
examples.ja: 審判のやつら、マジでいい加減にしろ！

examples.en: Viet was so angry that he couldn’t restrain himself from punching Koichi and screaming, "Cut it out!"
examples.ja: ビエトはあまりにも怒っていたので、コウイチを殴って「いい加減にしろ！」と叫ばずにはいられなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how いい加減 is unfounded or pointless? Because if you <kanji>add</kanji> and then <kanji>decrease</kanji> you haven't really done anything? Well, this is like saying "do the pointless!" Okay, that doesn't make any sense. This is a phrase that means something similar to <vocabulary>cut it out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cut the BS</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as いい加減, which you (hopefully) learned earlier.

examples.en: Everybody wants to avoid troublesome formalities!
examples.ja: みんな、面倒な手続きはしたくないよ！

examples.en: Last week I finished the process of enrolling my child in school.
examples.ja: 先週、子どもを学校に入学させる手続きを終えました。

examples.en: The procedure was very complicated and I got so confused that I didn't know what to do.
examples.ja: 手続きが複雑で、頭が混乱してどうしていいか分からなくなりました。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone takes your <kanji>hand</kanji> and shows you how to <kanji>continue</kanji>. "This is the <vocabulary>procedure</vocabulary>," they say. Move your hand like this. Verrrryyy goood. Good procedure. Good!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of 手 and 続く put together into one. Darn these body parts making everything kun'yomi.

examples.en: "Which side are you on, Fugu? Are you my enemy?" "I’m on your side, Salmon."
examples.ja: 「フグ、あなたはどっちの味方なの？私の敵なの？」「僕は君の味方だよ、サーモン。」

examples.en: Viet took matters into his own hands and headed to the enemy's hideout.
examples.ja: ビエトは自分だけの判断で、敵のアジトに向かった。

examples.en: I wish to exact revenge on that person for the sake of my parents someday.
examples.ja: いつかアイツに、親の敵を討ちたいんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

敵 means <vocabulary>enemy</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>opponent</vocabulary>, whether in war, sports, competitions, or other conflict situations. Just keep in mind that 敵 can sound a bit strong!
reading_mnemonic:
The main reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. But there's also a secondary かたき reading you haven't seen yet, so here's a mnemonic for that:

You love to call your <vocabulary>enemy</vocabulary>'s <reading>car tacky</reading> (かたき). They're always driving around in some tacky sports car, you can't stand it. Every time they drive by you shout, "Your car is tacky, enemy!"

Note: In terms of differences, the てき reading just means "enemy," whereas かたき typically refers to someone you hold a deep grudge against, often on behalf of another.

examples.en: Who do you think is Wanikani's rival?
examples.ja: ワニカニの大敵はだれだと思いますか？

examples.en: Our arch enemy finally acknowledged their defeat.
examples.ja: オレたちの大敵が、ついに敗北を認めたぞ。

examples.en: As you all know, carelessness is man's greatest enemy. People say "even monkeys fall from trees," right?
examples.ja: 分かっていると思うけど、油断大敵だよ。「サルも木から落ちる」って言うだろう？

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>enemy</kanji> is your worst enemy. Your <vocabulary>arch enemy</vocabulary>.

大敵 is for a powerful or dangerous opponent, whether it's a <vocabulary>formidable adversary</vocabulary> in battle or competition, or something abstract, like calling carelessness your <vocabulary>great enemy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Both kanji have a couple different on'yomi readings though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to pick:

Your <vocabulary>arch enemy</vocabulary> is the <reading>tie techie</reading> (たいてき). Who's the tie techie? He's the tech support guy at work who always wears the same tie and never helps you. He just says "try restarting your computer" to every problem, which isn't helpful. He's not just a great enemy, he's basically your nemesis. You hate that tie techie.

examples.en: Koichi is invincible at Shiritori.
examples.ja: しりとりで、コウイチは無敵だ。

examples.en: I wanna get plastic surgery to make people think that I'm an adorable, unrivaled woman.
examples.ja: 整形して、みんなから可愛すぎる無敵な女だって思われたい。

examples.en: Our son admires invincible heroes.
examples.ja: うちの息子は、無敵のヒーローに憧れています。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>nothing</kanji> when it comes to <kanji>enemies</kanji>. Why? It's not because you're super kind and everyone likes you. No, it's that you've defeated anyone who's tried. You are <vocabulary>unrivaled</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>invincible</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Work just came to an end.

examples.en: Let's get together in the cafeteria once we're done with this work!
examples.ja: この作業が済んだら食堂に集まろうぜ！

examples.en: I apologized, but he told me apologizing wouldn't end the problem, so I got angry and slapped him in the face.
examples.ja: 謝ったんだけど、「これは謝って済む問題じゃない」なんて言われちゃって、それで頭にきて彼の顔をひっぱたいちゃったのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>come to an end</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your romp finally has <vocabulary>to come to an end</vocabulary> when someone decides to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you for all your romping.

examples.en: That committee member has good judgment, doesn't she?

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>committee</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> is a <vocabulary>member of a committee</vocabulary> (or a <vocabulary>committee member</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When the teacher said that, many hands were raised.
examples.ja: 先生がそう言うと、たくさん手が挙がった。

examples.en: Tom's name was mentioned at the time, wasn't it?

examples.en: I can’t believe that I’m nominated for the Mustache Award.
examples.ja: 自分がヒゲ大賞の候補に挙がっているなんて、信じられないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>raise</kanji> something you are causing it <vocabulary>to be raised</vocabulary>. This verb can also mean things like <vocabulary>to be listed</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be nominated</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>. For these additional meanings, you might want to imagine something rising up onto a list or someone rising up to a nomination, because lists and nominations are always high up.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The reading for this is the same as the other "to rise" word, 上がる. Nice how that works, right? So, just associate the two and you have yourself a reading.

examples.en: Don't try to confuse me by bringing up things that don't have to do with the election.
examples.ja: 選挙の話と関係のないことを持ち出して、頭を混乱させるのは止めてくれ。

examples.en: Many people have been critical of the results of this election, and they say the whole thing should be redone.
examples.ja: 今回の選挙結果には多くの人が批判的で、もう一度選挙し直すべきだと言っています。

examples.en: Koichi lost his voice from singing the blues during his election speech.
examples.ja: コウイチは、選挙演説中にブルースを歌って声がつぶれた。

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>choose</kanji> someone and <kanji>raise</kanji> them up to office. This is an <vocabulary>election</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I ordered my personal seal at a seal store.
examples.ja: 判子屋さんで、判子を注文しました。

examples.en: Please sign here and put your seal there.
examples.ja: ここにはサイン、そこには判子をお願いします。

examples.en: This document was officially sealed by Koichi.
examples.ja: この書類には、コウイチによって公的な判子が押されています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>child</kanji> of a <kanji>judge</kanji> is the thing he puts on his judgements. What does he put on his judgments? His <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>, you know, to make it all official and stuff.
reading_mnemonic: 判 is the reading you learned. 子 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which I bet you know pretty well by now as well. You just have to remember to use it here.

examples.en: Was your high school uniform sailor-style or blazer-style?
examples.ja: 高校の制服はセーラー服だった？それともブレザーだった？

examples.en: Everybody acknowledges that that high school's uniforms are cute.
examples.ja: あの高校の制服が可愛いことは、みんな認めている。

examples.en: I want Aya to draw girls in school uniforms and integrate cubism style into it.
examples.ja: アヤに、制服を着た女の子の絵を、立体派の画風を取り込みながら描いてもらいたいんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>control</kanji> people, you make them wear the same <kanji>clothes</kanji>. That's a <vocabulary>uniform</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This guidebook for the new system is intended for beginners.
examples.ja: これは、新制度についての初心者向けガイドブックです。

examples.en: First, please start by telling us about Tofugu's educational system for its employees.
examples.ja: まず始めに、トーフグの社員教育制度の話を聞かせてください。

examples.en: If we ask Masao, he should be able to give us a sound judgement about that system.
examples.ja: マサオなら、その制度について健全な判断をしてくれるはずです。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>control</kanji> every <kanji>degree</kanji> of this <vocabulary>system</vocabulary>. Think about a system. It's designed to create more control for you, degree by degree by degree. That's why they call it "The system," after all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Ah, but doesn’t knowledge you were forced to learn just get quickly forgotten?
examples.ja: えー、でも、強制されて学んだ知識って、すぐ忘れちゃうじゃん？

examples.en: Of course all workers' participation in the company retreat is expected, but not mandatory.
examples.ja: もちろん全社員が社員旅行に参加することが望ましいけど、強制ではないですよ。

examples.en: My mother forced Fugu and I to move into this historic art-deco property.
examples.ja: 母は、フグと私がこのアール・デコ様式の建物に引っ越すよう強制しました。

meaning_mnemonic:
They have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> over us. This means they never stop <vocabulary>forcing</vocabulary> us into <vocabulary>compulsion</vocabulary>s or making all sorts of things <vocabulary>compulsory</vocabulary>.

強制 means making someone do something against their will, often through pressure, threats, or authority. It's used when someone is forced to sign a document under coercion, for example, or when someone is made to return to their country by force. 強制 means there's no choice in the matter.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I definitely prefer flamboyant styles, but I practice self restraint.
examples.ja: 私としては、断然フランボワイヤン様式の方が良かったんですが、そこはまぁ自制しています。

examples.en: When I start drinking, I tend to loose the ability to control myself.
examples.ja: お酒を飲み始めると、自制がうまくきかなくなるんです。

examples.en: People who don't have self restraint shouldn't invest in stocks.
examples.ja: 自制の出来ない人は、株式投資はしない方がいい。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Self</kanji> <kanji>control</kanji> is <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self restraint</vocabulary>. Have some!

examples.en: My father worked as a police officer for forty years until last year.
examples.ja: 父は去年まで四十年間警察官を務めました。

examples.en: Koichi served an important role of taking care of aliens from various planets.
examples.ja: コウイチは色々な星からやってきた宇宙人をお世話するという大役を務めた。

examples.en: Mr. Tamura was employed as Ms. Tanaka’s private secretary for one year, but it didn’t really work out.
examples.ja: 田村さんは田中さんの個人秘書を一年間務めたんだけど、あまりうまくいかなかったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>task</kanji> so what's the verb vocab version? Well, when you do a task, you are going <vocabulary>to work as</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to serve as</vocabulary> something to do that task.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>To work as</vocabulary> my secretary, you will have to complete a task. A task where you bring me <reading>two toe</reading>s (つと)! Don't ask me why! You want <vocabulary>to serve as</vocabulary> my assistant, right? Just get me those two toes then!

examples.en: Smoking is not allowed in this office.
examples.ja: この事務所では、喫煙は認められていません。

examples.en: There's not a dime of extra money in this office.
examples.ja: この事務所には、余計な金はビタ一文も無いんだよ。

examples.en: Let me quickly show you around the Tofugu office.
examples.ja: 当社トーフグの事務所を簡単にご案内させてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
When the <kanji>occurrence</kanji> of your <kanji>task</kanji>s is in the same <kanji>place</kanji> every day, that place is probably an <vocabulary>office</vocabulary>.

事務所 is often for office spaces that handle back-office 事務 (administrative or clerical work). It can also be used for offices that offer more specialized services, like a 会計事務所 (accounting <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>) or 芸能事務所 (talent <vocabulary>agency</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Many people say that doing housework is a wife’s obligation to her husband and children, but is that really true?
examples.ja: 家事をするのは、夫と子どもに対する妻の義務だと言う人が多くいますが、果たしてそれは本当でしょうか？

examples.en: The umpire has a duty to make fair calls.
examples.ja: 審判は、公平な判断を下す義務があります。

examples.en: But then, wouldn't that be a breach of confidentiality?
examples.ja: それって、守秘義務の違反になるんじゃないですか？

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>righteousness</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is my <vocabulary>obligation</vocabulary> to these people. I will go out and purge the world of evil, be righteous, and make things happen. It's my <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.ja: 今朝のニュース番組で、キャスターが国会議員の任務について解説していたのを見ただけだよ。

examples.en: Koichi told me that I'm not allowed to leave before completing the mission.
examples.ja: 任務完了前に撤退することは許されないとコウイチに言われました。

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>duty</kanji>. You have a <kanji>task</kanji>. You have both a <vocabulary>duty</vocabulary> and a <vocabulary>task</vocabulary> to do.

meaning_mnemonic: When you take the <kanji>whole</kanji> and <kanji>join</kanji> it together, you get a <vocabulary>synthesis</vocabulary>, and probably a good <vocabulary>overall</vocabulary> picture of things.

examples.ja: この旅では色々な事件が起きましたが、総体的にはとても楽しかったです。

examples.en: Exercising every day has improved my life overall.

examples.ja: 我々は、お客様に総体的に満足して頂けるよう努力しています。

examples.en: I heard a rumor that Tofugu is finally going to set up a branch in Japan, but I wonder if it's true.
examples.ja: トーフグがついに日本支店を設けるというウワサを聞いたんだけど、本当かな？

examples.en: I heard that the president is planning to set up a sauna in the office this time.
examples.ja: 社長、今度はオフィスにサウナを設けるつもりらしいですよ。

examples.en: Apparently Koichi is considering establishing new rules for his employees.
examples.ja: コウイチは、新しい従業員規則を設けることを検討しているようです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>establish</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to set up</vocabulary>.

設ける is a formal word that suggests setting up something in order to prep for future needs or events. If you want to ensure smooth operation or governance, for example, you might set up rules (ルールを設ける) or establish an office (オフィスを設ける). You can even use it to say you’ll arrange a drinking party (酒の席を設ける), in which case it probably means the party has a more formal purpose like networking or discussion.
reading_mnemonic: What are you going <vocabulary>to establish</vocabulary>? How about a system for <reading>mow</reading>ing (もう) lawns? It's very important that lawns are mowed according to an established system, you know. How do you mow yours?

examples.en: I set up a new business mail account in Google for you.
examples.ja: あなたの新しいビジネス用のメールアカウントを、グーグルに設定しました。

examples.en: What temperature do you usually set your air conditioner to?
examples.ja: クーラーはいつも何度に設定していますか？

examples.en: I have to set up two-factor authentications with all the accounts I have by the end of day or I'll get fired.
examples.ja: 今日中に全てのアカウントの二段階認証を設定しないと、会社を首になるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
What do you <kanji>establish</kanji> and <kanji>determine</kanji> in your every day life? A setting. When you make that into a verb, you have the word <vocabulary>to set</vocabulary>, as in setting the temperature of the AC, setting your password, or setting your computer to dark mode.

設定する is a little formal, but does get commonly used for device, system, and game settings. It's also often used in more official contexts, like for setting prices for products or establishing project goals.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Careful because the 設 gets shortened to せっ.

examples.en: Starting next year we will establish a public committee.
examples.ja: 来年度から、公設の委員会を設けることになりました。

examples.en: If I remember correctly, I think there is a public restroom in that park.
examples.ja: 確かあの公園に公設の便所があったはずだよ。

examples.en: If you travel to Okinawa, you should go to Makishi Public Market.
examples.ja: もし沖縄を旅行するなら、牧志公設市場に行った方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>establish</kanji>ment. It is <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.
