examples.en: The Pantheon was built in the Campus Martius in the city of Rome.
examples.ja: パンテオンは、ローマ市内のマルス広場に建設されました。

examples.en: Is that airport still under construction? I wonder if it'll ever get finished.
examples.ja: その空港、まだ建設中なの？本当に完成するのかな？

examples.en: Who's gonna rebuild the buildings that Godzilla destroyed?
examples.ja: ゴジラが破壊したビルは、だれが建設し直すの？

meaning_mnemonic:
You do the <kanji>build</kanji>ing to <kanji>establish</kanji> something. This whole process is called <vocabulary>construction</vocabulary>!

建設 is a pretty formal word for construction, focusing on the action or process of <vocabulary>constructing</vocabulary> rather than the structure itself. It’s often used for large construction projects, like malls, dams, or bridges. In some contexts, it can also refer to the <vocabulary>establishment</vocabulary> of significant entities, like a new state.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There's a reason for the venture capital shortage.
examples.ja: ベンチャー・キャピタル、いわゆる冒険資本が不足するには、ワケがあります。

examples.en: What was the formula for calculating the turnover ratio of capital?
examples.ja: 資本回転率を求める公式ってどんなのだったっけ？

examples.en: I'm wondering if I should start my business with outside funds or shareholders' funds.
examples.ja: 他人資本と株主資本で、どちらの資本でビジネスを始めるか迷っています。

meaning_mnemonic: To start a business, your <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>resource</kanji> is your <vocabulary>capital</vocabulary>, which can be money and various other types of assets, like real estate properties.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You don't need a lot of capital to start a new business.
examples.ja: あまり資金がなくても、新しい事業は始められますよ。

examples.en: When we started running out of capital, we met that person in Paris.
examples.ja: 資金が底をつき始めたときに、パリであのお方にお会いしたのです。

examples.en: Tofugu invested a great deal of capital into YouTube content production.
examples.ja: トーフグは、YouTubeのコンテンツ制作に多額の資金を投じました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>resources</kanji> of <kanji>gold</kanji> that we have are our current <vocabulary>funds</vocabulary>. 

資金 is specifically for monetary funds, not other types of assets. That 金 kanji can mean money, so it should be easy to remember.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The various materials were mixed up in the box.
examples.ja: 色んな資料が、箱の中で混ぜこぜになっていました。

examples.en: The police officer had solved the case using only the information in the documents.
examples.ja: その警察官は、資料の情報だけで事件を解決してしまった。

examples.en: If you don’t mind, would I be able to send you some data?
examples.ja: もしよろしければ、いくつか資料をお送りさせて頂けませんでしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you use <kanji>resources</kanji> to make <kanji>material</kanji>, you'll have <vocabulary>material</vocabulary>. This is in the sense of material for a book, or <vocabulary>data</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>documents</vocabulary> for research.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don’t want to get involved in high risk investments.
examples.ja: リスクの高い投資商品にまで手を出したくはないんです。

examples.en: Koichi asked Viet for an investment decision.
examples.ja: コウイチは、ビエトに投資判断を求めました。

examples.en: If you invest, do so at your own risk.
examples.ja: 投資するなら自己責任でやらないといけませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Go ahead and <kanji>throw</kanji> your <kanji>resources</kanji> at the project. It could use the <vocabulary>investment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

examples.en: December 10th is Human Rights Day.
examples.ja: 十二月十日は世界人権デーです。

examples.en: You shouldn’t work for a company that disrespects human rights.
examples.ja: 人権を軽んじるような企業で働かない方がいいよ。

examples.en: Some people say that dress codes can violate human rights. What do you think about that?
examples.ja: 服装規定が人権侵害にあたることがあるという人もいますが、それについてどう思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>People</kanji> <kanji>Rights</kanji> are <vocabulary>human rights</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: We have the right to object.
examples.ja: 私たちには反対する権利があります。

examples.en: This is a citizen's right.
examples.ja: これは国民の権利です。

examples.en: In Japan, the eligible age for voting rights was lowered from twenty to eighteen.
examples.ja: 日本では、選挙で投票する権利が20才から18才に引き下げられました。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>rights</kanji> to <kanji>profit</kanji>! This is <vocabulary>a right</vocabulary> you have!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Hearing those terms had me wide awake.
examples.ja: その条件を聞いて、すっかり目が覚めたよ。

examples.en: Fugu, you can go to the drinking party on Friday night, but on one condition - you can’t drink alcohol.
examples.ja: フグ、金曜の夜の飲み会に行ってもいいけど、一つだけ条件があるわ。お酒は飲まないでね。

examples.en: Why would you throw away a job with such good work conditions?
examples.ja: こんな条件のいい仕事、どうして棒に振っちゃったのさ？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>clause</kanji> in the <kanji>matter</kanji> complicates things. It adds <vocabulary>conditions</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>terms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>requirements</vocabulary> to an otherwise simple matter.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There was an incident on my way to work.
examples.ja: 会社に向かっていると、ある事件が起こった。

examples.en: Report back to me as soon as possible about the incident regarding Koichi's stolen underwear.
examples.ja: この「盗まれたコウイチの下着」事件について、できるだけ早く報告してください。

examples.en: The case in which Fugu stole and ate one of the Crabigator's arms one year ago finally reached an amicable settlement.
examples.ja: 一年前に起きた、フグがワニカニの腕を一本盗んで食べるという事件がようやく和解に至りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>occurrence</kanji> of some <kanji>matter</kanji> is really just something that happens. It's an <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>case</vocabulary>. 

事件 often refers to significant or serious occurrences like crime cases or accidents. It can also be used playfully — "There was a 事件 at the party!" — to dramatize an event like someone asking out your classmate.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't want to be a bridesmaid because the dresses are too flashy.
examples.ja: ドレスが派手すぎるから、ブライズ・メイドにはなりたくないんだよね。

examples.en: Showy fashion was the trend about 30 years ago in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本では三十年ほど前は派手なファッションが流行していました。

examples.en: That girl may look gaudy, but despite appearances she's actually very sensitive on the inside.
examples.ja: あの子、見た目は派手だけどああ見えて中身はとても繊細なのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a weird one. Just think about the <kanji>sect</kanji> of <kanji>hand</kanji>s. They are always doing jazz hands and things like that, trying to be all <vocabulary>showy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>flashy</vocabulary>. Ugh, what a dumb sect, you think.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, though て goes to で.

examples.en: That company is only admirable on the surface.
examples.ja: あの会社、うわべだけは立派だよね。

examples.en: You've become such a splendid movie critic.
examples.ja: お前も立派な映画評論家になったもんだなぁ。

examples.en: My cat grew very handsome whiskers, so I named him Hige.
examples.ja: 私の猫は立派な髯を生やしているので、「ヒゲ」と名付けました。

meaning_mnemonic:
People are <kanji>stand</kanji>ing and forming a <kanji>sect</kanji> for you because of the <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> things you say and do. Your <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> conduct has brought them to their feet, and now they're worshipping you like some new age guru.

立派 is a slightly formal word used to say something or someone is <vocabulary>impressive</vocabulary>. For example, you might call someone who achieved something great a 立派な人, or describe an elegant, expensive-looking building as a 立派な建物. Even a fine, majestic mustache could be called a 立派なヒゲ!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The りつ shortens to りっ though, so keep an eye on that you splendid frood you. Oh and は changes to ぱ too. Because rendaku and all that.

examples.en: My father is from Okayama Prefecture.
examples.ja: 私の父は岡山県出身です。

examples.en: The earthquake brought utter chaos to Okayama prefecture.
examples.ja: 岡山県は、地震で大混乱となりました。

examples.en: The suspect admits that he stole the money in Okayama prefecture.
examples.ja: 容疑者は、岡山県で金を盗んだことを認めています。

meaning_mnemonic: Okayama (岡山) <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> is a prefecture in Japan. Learning the reading will help you to remember the meaning of this word since half of it is in Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the first two kanji. Luckily you learned them when you learned the kanji. Then, stick 県 on there and you should be good to go!

examples.en: Aya was right in her decision to go with that raw material.
examples.ja: その素材を選んだアヤの判断は正しかった。

examples.en: In this restaurant, seasoning is kept to a minimum for you to enjoy the natural taste of the ingredients.
examples.ja: このレストランでは、素材そのものの味を楽しんでもらうため、味付けはひかえめにしています。

examples.en: I'm looking for copyright-free materials.
examples.ja: 著作権フリーの素材を探しています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you want to use the most basic <kanji>element</kanji>s of a <kanji>material</kanji>, you end up with <vocabulary>raw material</vocabulary>s. Maybe it's the raw materials you're going to use to build a house. Maybe it's the raw materials you need to make a good soup. Either way, they haven't been touched much (yet).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 素 is the そ reading, so be careful. You can remember by thinking how you have to <reading>sew</reading> the building together using these raw materials.

examples.en: Do you think I should refuse the job?
examples.ja: その仕事、断るべきだと思う？

examples.en: Viet was appointed as the next Secretary of State, but he refused.
examples.ja: ビエトは次期国務長官に任命されたが、断った。

examples.en: I was asked to be the chief umpire for a baseball game, but I rejected the offer. I would have done it if it was for the chief referee of a soccer game though.
examples.ja: 野球の試合の主審を頼まれたけど、断りました。サッカーの試合の主審だったら引き受けたんだけどね。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cut off</kanji>. What happens when you do the action of cutting someone off? You're going <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary> them whatever it is they want.
reading_mnemonic: Deciding <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary> something unfortunately starts a <reading>coat war</reading> (like a pillow fight, but everyone hits each other with coats instead of pillows). Coats to the ready, and let the coat war commence!

examples.en: My judgment was wrong.
examples.ja: 私の判断は間違っていた。

examples.en: If I hadn't made the wrong decision then, I would have gotten extremely rich.
examples.ja: あの時、判断を誤らなければ、大金持ちになれていたのに。

examples.en: It is difficult for an amateur to judge whether a mushroom is edible or poisonous.
examples.ja: 食用キノコか毒キノコの判断は、素人には難しい。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>judge</kanji> to <kanji>cut off</kanji> your head. That is my <vocabulary>judgment</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Sometimes you can’t help but be the subject of criticism.
examples.ja: 批判の的となっても仕方がないと思っている。

examples.en: I'm trying to look at everything as critically as possible.
examples.ja: できるだけ批判的な目であらゆる物事を見るよう心がけています。

examples.en: Viet was severely criticized for taking bribes from the yakuza.
examples.ja: ビエトは暴力団から賄賂を受け取ったことを厳しく批判されました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>criticism</kanji> is when you <kanji>judge</kanji>. It is still just a <vocabulary>criticism</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You can follow me on a voluntary basis.
examples.ja: フォローは任意です。

examples.en: Please choose any 8-digit number.
examples.ja: 任意の八ケタの数字を選んでください。

examples.en: Do I legally have to tell you my name and address, or is it optional?
examples.ja: 名前と住所は法律で答えなくてはいけないと決まっているものですか？それとも任意ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>idea</kanji> of <kanji>duty</kanji> is that you don't really have to do it. It's <vocabulary>optional</vocabulary>, you know?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I received a checkup at the hospital.
examples.ja: 病院で検査を受けました。

examples.en: Upon inspection, we could not find anything wrong with the engine.
examples.ja: 検査の結果、エンジンには何も問題ありませんでした。

examples.en: I'm surprised pinworm tests aren't commonly administered in North America.
examples.ja: 北米でギョウ虫検査があまり一般的ではないなんて、驚きです。

meaning_mnemonic: We're going to need to <kanji>examine</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> you for our annual <vocabulary>checkup</vocabulary>, mmk? Now drop your pants and cough, please.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Hey look, the police are examining people over there.
examples.ja: ほら、あそこで警察が検問しているよ。

examples.en: While the police were inspecting my car, my heart was racing.
examples.ja: 警察が私の車を検問している時、ドキドキしました。

examples.en: Some of the security guards who inspect people at Narita Airport's checkpoints are undergoing training.
examples.ja: 成田空港の検問所で検問している警備員の中には、トレーニング中の警備員もいます。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>examine</kanji> the <kanji>problem</kanji>. In order to do this, you need <vocabulary>to inspect</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>to examine</vocabulary> it. And if you're inspecting people like this, you're probably the police.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My older brother took out three books on the Treaty of Paris and two on Treaty of Versailles from the library.
examples.ja: 兄は図書館からパリ条約に関する本を三冊とヴェルサイユ条約に関する本を二冊借りてきました。

examples.en: This treaty was made based on the committee's conclusion.
examples.ja: この条約は、委員会の判断に基いて取り決められたものです。

examples.en: Koichi’s New Year’s resolution is memorizing the entire text of the Treaty of Versailles.
examples.ja: コウイチの今年の抱負は、ベルサイユ条約の全文を暗記することです。

meaning_mnemonic: There are many <kanji>clause</kanji>s about the <kanji>promise</kanji>s you make in this contract considering it's supposed to be a <vocabulary>treaty</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: "I should have checked it out myself." "Don’t blame yourself. It wasn’t your fault."
examples.ja: 「自分でちゃんとチェックするべきだったよ。」「そんなに自分を責めないで。あなたのせいじゃないわよ。」

examples.en: The typhoon disrupted the train schedule, so blaming Michael is unreasonable.
examples.ja: 台風で電車のダイヤが混乱してただけなんだから、マイケルさんを責めるのはおかしいよ。

examples.en: Our kid had a fever, but I messed up and didn't take him to the hospital, so he ended up with pneumonia. My wife later reproached me harshly.
examples.ja: 子どもが熱を出したんだけど、判断を誤って病院に連れて行かなかったら肺炎になっちゃってね。後で妻からひどく責められたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blame</kanji> so this also means <vocabulary>to blame</vocabulary>. Additionally, this can also mean <vocabulary>to criticize</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to reproach</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to accuse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Are you going <vocabulary>to blame</vocabulary> me for eating your <reading>ce</reading>lery (せ)? You should know I'm the wrong person to blame because I don't even like celery!

examples.en: Japanese salarymen tend to hate taking responsibility.
examples.ja: 日本のサラリーマンは責任を取る事を嫌がることが多い。

examples.en: When the clock struck seven, I awoke from a terrible dream that Koichi was forcing me to take responsibility for all of my WaniKani errors.
examples.ja: 時計が七時を打つ音で、コウイチからワニカニのエラーの全ての責任を負わされるというおそろしい夢から目覚めました。

examples.en: Why don't we reserve judgement on whoever's responsibility it was, and just start by making up for lost time?
examples.ja: 責任が誰にあるかの判断は一旦保留にして、まずは遅れを取り戻そう。

meaning_mnemonic: You can <kanji>blame</kanji> <kanji>duty</kanji> all you want, but you still have a <vocabulary>responsibility</vocabulary> as well, no matter what your duty dictates.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I've been very busy these days, so I've been skipping meal prep and just buying to-go dinners.
examples.ja: 最近はとても忙しいので、夕食を作る手間を省いてテイクアウトばかりしています。

examples.en: A lot of the explanations were left out, so I couldn't understand it.
examples.ja: 説明がたくさん省かれていたので理解できませんでした。

examples.en: This robot was supposed to save us a lot of labor, but the situation remains unchanged.
examples.ja: このロボットが多くの人手を省くはずだったが、状況は変化しないままである。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conserve</kanji>... but why stop there when you could try <vocabulary>to omit</vocabulary> everything and <vocabulary>to eliminate</vocabulary> everything? Just take exactly what you need, conserve it, and omit everything else.
reading_mnemonic: You <reading>have</reading> (はぶ) what you have, and omit what you don't need. Perfect life.

examples.en: I’ve been reflecting on it, so please don’t be so hard on me.
examples.ja: 反省しているので、そんなにきつく当たらないでください。

examples.en: My younger brother reconsidered it even more than I did.
examples.ja: 弟は、私よりも余計に反省していた。

examples.en: President Koichi and Vice President Viet held a postmortem meeting.
examples.ja: コウイチ大統領とビエト副大統領は反省会を開いた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> <kanji>conserve</kanji>, I'm going to ask you to do some heavy <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reflection</vocabulary>, and see if that's really the right way to be. If you change your thinking, you might even end up showing <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading for 反 is all good. The reading for 省 is an on'yomi reading you haven't seen yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

I'm standing in front of you, forcing a <vocabulary>reconsideration</vocabulary> of your anti conserve stance, with my <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) to your throat. I better see some reflection on your face or you won't have one in a second.

examples.en: Over the past few years, Viet’s daily amount of alcohol has been considerably increasing.
examples.ja: ここ2、3年、ビエトが一日に飲むお酒、かなり増えてるんだよね。

examples.en: It would be nice if the constructive criticism increased a bit.
examples.ja: もう少し建設的な批判が増えるといいんだけど。

examples.en: It felt like the number of gray hairs mixed into my mom's black hair had increased since I last saw her.
examples.ja: 母の黒髪に交じった白髪の量が、以前より増えている気がした。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>increase</kanji>, so the vocabulary verb version means <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary>. This is when something is just increasing on its own, and you're not doing the increasing. You know this because you like to <reading>err</reading> (える) on the side of caution and not touch anything when it's increasing, therefore you're not doing any of the increasing yourself (it's just happening).

This is an everyday word that refers to an increase in number or quantity, but keep in mind that it cannot be used to express an increase in degree.
reading_mnemonic: It would be <reading>foo</reading>lish (ふ) of you to touch anything while things are increasing anyways. You don't want to mess up a good thing, do you? Don't be a fool.

examples.en: Crimes have been increasing steadily since Viet left town.
examples.ja: ビエトがこの町を去ってから、 犯罪は着実に増加している。

examples.en: The number of Japanese restaurants have been increasing around here.
examples.ja: この辺りでは、日本食レストランの数が増加しています。

examples.en: I ate way too much mochi on New Years and my weight increased by 50 kilos.
examples.ja: お正月に餅を食べ過ぎて、体重が五十キロも増加した。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>increase</kanji> will <kanji>add</kanji> to what you had before. This is an <vocabulary>increase</vocabulary>.

This word refers to an increase in number or quantity, often used in formal contexts, reports, or news articles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What do you think about the sudden increase in the number of young people who lack self-control in recent years, Dr. Fugu?
examples.ja: 近年の、自制心が欠けている若者の急増について、フグ先生はどうお考えですか。

examples.en: I feel that there's been a sudden increase in the number of people who can't accept even the slightest criticism.
examples.ja: ちょっとした批判も受け入れられない人が急増している気がします。

examples.en: The number of children who dream of being a choreographer has increased suddenly.
examples.ja: 振り付け師になるのが夢だという子どもが、急増しています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>increase</kanji> is just that, a <vocabulary>sudden increase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>surge</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I will never accept a tax increase.
examples.ja: 増税するなんて、ゼッタイに認めません。

examples.en: Because of the tax increase, I had to pay an extra 50 yen.
examples.ja: 増税のせいで、五十円余計にかかった。

examples.en: In the bill that just came, my property tax has been increased by 50%, but that’s a mistake, right? At least I hope it is.
examples.ja: さっき届いた請求書の固定資産税が、50%も増税されてたんだけど、間違いだよね。そうであってほしい。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>increase</kanji> <kanji>tax</kanji> you're doing a <vocabulary>tax increase</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It's completely unacceptable that he uses our tax dollars for golf, right?
examples.ja: 税金でゴルフに参加するとか、ありえなくない？

examples.en: I wanted to study taxes, but it looks like it's too difficult for a blowfish like me.
examples.ja: 税金の勉強をしたかったのですが、どうやらフグの私には難しすぎたようです。

examples.en: My parents only adopted you because they needed the tax deduction.
examples.ja: 私の両親があなたを養子縁組したのは、ただ税金の控除を受けたかったのが理由です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tax</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> is what you have to pay when you have to pay a <vocabulary>tax</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I wish alcohol was tax-free.
examples.ja: お酒が無税だったらいいのにな。

examples.en: Dubai is known as a tax-free country, but they basically just use the word "fee" instead of "tax."
examples.ja: ドバイは無税の国として知られていますが、実際は税金の代わりに手数料という名目が使われているだけです。

examples.en: In Japan, you can gift up to 1,100,000 yen annually with no tax.
examples.ja: 日本では年間110万円までは無税で贈与できる。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>tax</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> things are <vocabulary>tax free</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Actually, I'd say nobody would notice even if an alien mixed in with the crowd.
examples.ja: 実際、宇宙人が人ごみに混じっていても、だれも気が付かないだろう。

examples.en: Nobody knows that man's real mission.
examples.ja: あの男の実際の任務については、だれも知らないんだ。

examples.en: How many clients does Tofugu actually have at the moment?
examples.ja: 今現在、実際にトーフグは何名の顧客を抱えているのですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>truth</kanji> <kanji>occasion</kanji> is <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary>. This word is also used a lot as an adverb (with or without the particle に) to mean <vocabulary>actually</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>really</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The つ is shortened to っ.

examples.en: Koichi is going to announce the development of Tofugu at an international conference.
examples.ja: コウイチは国際会議でトーフグの開発成果について発表する予定です。

examples.en: I decided to go to an international university, because I want to work in an international field.
examples.ja: 国際的なフィールドで仕事がしたいと思ったので、国際大学に行くことにしました。

examples.en: We make diplomatic efforts every day to resolve all kinds of international crises and maintain international peace.
examples.ja: あらゆる国際危機を解決し、国際の平和を維持するため、日々外交努力を行っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <kanji> occasion</kanji> to check out another <kanji>country</kanji>. Wow, so <vocabulary>international</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When I was standing at the edge of the cliff, suddenly a strong wind blew and it made my heart skip a beat.
examples.ja: ガケの際に立っていたら、急に強い風がふいてきてドキッとした。

examples.en: There is a flower decorating the side of the window.
examples.ja: 窓際に一輪の花が飾ってある。

examples.en: The color around the edge of the dial on this watch is subtly fading.
examples.ja: この時計、ダイヤルの際のところの色がビミョーにうすくなってるね。

examples.en: I use a liquid liner to trace along my upper lashes and draw a line along the edge of my upper eyelid.
examples.ja: 私は、リキッドライナーは、上まつ毛の上をなぞるようにして、上まぶたの際に引くようにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: Even though the kanji mainly means <kanji>occasion</kanji>, for some reason this word means <vocabulary>side</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary>. I suppose on <kanji>occasion</kanji> kanji takes you to the <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of what ought to make sense when it comes to kanji.
reading_mnemonic:
You're on the very <vocabulary>edge</vocabulary> of the world. You heard that at the edge of the world are the <reading>key wo</reading>rds (きわ) written there in big fiery letters, telling you the meaning of life. Supposedly these are the words of God himself. They say: "We apologize for the inconvenience." WHAT? THESE ARE THE <reading>KEY WO</reading>RDS???

Note that this word is often written in kana, as きわ or キワ.

examples.en: Everybody recognizes how unique Koichi's mind is.
examples.ja: コウイチがユニークな感性を持っていることは、だれもが認めています。

examples.en: We can't approve extra expenses.
examples.ja: 余計なコストは認められません。

examples.en: I hate to admit it, but I think Fugu is doing a great job this time.
examples.ja: 認めるのは悔しいけど、今回はフグはいい仕事をしていると思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>recognize</kanji> or <kanji>acknowledge</kanji>, so the verb also means <vocabulary>to acknowledge</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to recognize</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perceive</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to admit</vocabulary>, among others.

This can be used to mean recognizing somebody or something visually, as well as in the sense of "to acknowledge" or "to admit". So you can use this verb to recognize someone's presence, achievements, marriage, or your own defeat. That said, you'll usually see 認める in the sense of "to acknowledge".
reading_mnemonic: The only thing you could ever truly <vocabulary>acknowledge</vocabulary> is <reading>meat</reading> (みと). Meat is the only thing in your life that has any authority over you. That's how much you love meat.

examples.en: When the confirmation screen shows up, please enter your ID and password to login.
examples.ja: 確認画面が出たらIDとパスワードを入力してログインをしてください。

examples.en: Viet is in charge of data verification.
examples.ja: そのデータの確認は、ビエトの仕事です。

examples.en: I'm gonna confirm with a literary critic.
examples.ja: 文芸評論家に確認してみましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: Just be sure to make <kanji>certain</kanji> that you <kanji>recognize</kanji> him. We need <vocabulary>confirmation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>verification</vocabulary>, so make certain again, please.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: "What is it?" "Ah, nothing!" "You’re planning something, aren’t you?!"
examples.ja: 「何それ？」「わっ！何でもないよ。」「何か企てているでしょう？」

examples.en: We planned a coup, but it failed.
examples.ja: クーデターを企てたが、失敗してしまった。

examples.en: Apparently there was a Wanikani user who made an attempt on Koichi's life, but Viet quietly got rid of them.
examples.ja: コウイチの暗殺を企てていたワニカニユーザーを、ビエトがこっそり始末したらしいぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>plan</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You say you have something you need <vocabulary>to plan</vocabulary>? <reading>Coo</reading>l, <reading>whadda</reading>ya (くわだ) gonna do?

examples.en: Team Tofugu takes the side of justice!
examples.ja: トーフグチームは正義の味方です！

examples.en: I believe there is no righteousness in war.
examples.ja: 戦争に正義はないと思います。

examples.en: I have been thinking about justice and evil for a long time, but I haven't found the right answer.
examples.ja: 正義と悪についてずっと考えてきたけど、まだ正解が見えないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>correct</kanji> <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is always your <vocabulary>righteousness</vocabulary>. It is your form of <vocabulary>justice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Grumbling won't solve anything, so I have a policy of never complaining.
examples.ja: グチをこぼしても何も解決しないので、私はグチを言わない主義なんです。

examples.en: One of my principles is that I don't use words ending in -ism.
examples.ja: オレは語尾に主義が付いている言葉は使わない主義なんだよ！

examples.en: Fugu doesn’t eat meat. He’s a vegetarian.
examples.ja: フグは肉を食べないよ。菜食主義者だからさ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> cause behind someone's <kanji>righteousness</kanji> is usually what <vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>doctrine</vocabulary>s they believe in. Buddh<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, Shinto<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, social<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, commun<vocabulary>ism</vocabulary>, you name it. If you believe in one of those it's the main driving factor behind what you believe righteousness to be.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I bought an obligatory box of chocolates for my father in law.
examples.ja: 義理の父に義理チョコを買いました。

examples.en: When I was talking with my older sister-in-law, I said more than I meant to.
examples.ja: 義理の姉と話をしている時に、つい余計な事を言ってしまったんです。

examples.en: Viet is a man who has a strong sense of duty.
examples.ja: ビエトはとても義理堅い男だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You have <kanji>righteousness</kanji> and then a <kanji>reason</kanji> behind it, at least in your own mind. This is your <vocabulary>sense of duty</vocabulary>. And it really is a "sense" in a way, too. You just feel it. It's not an actual thing that is tangible. It is your own personal reason for this righteousness.

This word can also mean <vocabulary>in-law</vocabulary> like your mother-in-law, because they're your mother in the social obligation sense only, not by blood.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What’s the definition of spam mail?
examples.ja: スパムメールの定義は何ですか？

examples.en: It took Koichi days to define "Americans."
examples.ja: コウイチは何日もかけて「アメリカ人」を定義した。

examples.en: When we introduce a new word, we always have to define the word.
examples.ja: 新しい単語を導入する時は、必ずその単語について定義しなければなりません。

meaning_mnemonic: Please <kanji>determine</kanji> what <kanji>righteousness</kanji> means. I want the <vocabulary>definition</vocabulary> for it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm going to participate in a discussion held by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs sometime soon.
examples.ja: 今度、外務省のディベートに参加してくるよ。

examples.en: I heard a rumor that Michael has a friend who is a big shot in the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications.
examples.ja: マイケルの友達の中には、総務省のおえらいさんもいるってウワサだよ。

examples.en: Mr. Viet, Senior Deputy Director General, International Bureau, Ministry of Finance, is on a diet right now and substitutes sugar with saccharin, so don't use sugar in his meal.
examples.ja: ビエト財務省国際局次長は現在ダイエット中であり、砂糖の代わりにサッカリンを用いているため、彼の食事には砂糖を使用しないでください。

meaning_mnemonic:
What should you establish to <kanji>conserve</kanji> a country? The <vocabulary>Ministry of</vocabulary>… well, any ministry really. In Japanese, 〜省 often gets tacked on to the names of government ministries. Like the Ministry of Finance (財務省), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (外務省), and the mouthful that is the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (文部科学省). Whew!

〜省 is also the suffix used for Chinese <vocabulary>province</vocabulary>s, such as 広東省 (Guangdong Province), so keep this in mind when reading about international affairs.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I really want to eat sashimi.
examples.ja: めっちゃお刺身が食べたい。

examples.en: Please give me squid sashimi for one.
examples.ja: イカの刺身を一人前下さい。

examples.en: Go get some sashimi from the supermarket!
examples.ja: 刺身をスーパーで買ってきて！

examples.en: After the meeting, we plan to have lunch at a restaurant that has an excellent sashimi bento.
examples.ja: 会合の後、素晴らしい刺身弁当があるレストランで昼食を予定しています。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 身 can mean "animal flesh"? Well, when you <kanji>stab</kanji> some animal flesh and eat it raw, you're having <vocabulary>sashimi</vocabulary>. Yum!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.

examples.en: I plan to work on my days off to make up for the time I took off due to illness.
examples.ja: 病気で休んだ分を休日に働いて埋め合わせるつもりだ。

examples.en: Do you think it's possible to compensate for a lack of intelligence with money?
examples.ja: 知性が足りないのを金で埋め合わせることはできると思う？

examples.en: Can’t we make up for this loss in some way or another?
examples.ja: どうにかこの損失を埋め合わせることはできないだろうか。

meaning_mnemonic: 埋める is "to bury." 合わせる is "to unify together." If you bury somebody in order to unify them with you, you're almost certainly trying <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 埋める and 合わせる. Combine them into one big happy word.

examples.en: Today’s lesson was on na-adjectives.
examples.ja: 今日のレッスンは形容動詞でした。

examples.en: I mixed up na-adjectives with i-adjectives and now I'm really confused.
examples.ja: 頭の中で、形容動詞と形容詞が混ぜこぜになってしまっていて、かなり混乱しています。

examples.en: I found it difficult to judge whether it was a na-adjective or just an i-adjective.
examples.ja: それが形容動詞なのかただの形容詞なのか、判断に迷いました。

meaning_mnemonic: A 形容詞 is an <kanji>adjective</kanji>. So what about an adjective with a 動詞 (verb) in there? How does that make sense? I'm not entirely sure either, but an adjective with movement in it is a <vocabulary>na adjective</vocabulary>. These are the adjectives that can end with な (便利な, for example). In fact, they're more like nouns than they are verbs, so what gives? Whatever it is, just decide you don't want to deal with this craziness. Just say <reading>nah</reading>, I don't care about this anymore.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 形容詞 and 動詞 as well, since they're both parts of this word.

examples.en: The teacher’s explanation is really easy to understand.
examples.ja: あの先生の解説はとても分かり易いね。

examples.en: I left at the beginning of the commentary on "The Last Judgment."
examples.ja: 最後の審判の解説の冒頭で席を立ちました。

examples.en: As for Tofugu's equity ratio, the president will explain it later.
examples.ja: トーフグの自己資本比率については、後ほど社長が解説します。

meaning_mnemonic:
Once you've <kanji>solve</kanji>d a <kanji>theory</kanji>, you should be able to give a pretty good <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> of it to somebody else. Makes sense, right? 

解説 refers to a detailed and analytical explanation. It's often used when someone, often an expert, provides an in-depth analysis about a topic, like a sports game or news article <vocabulary>commentary</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I stitched lace into cloth.
examples.ja: レースを布地にたたきつけた。

examples.en: I made kimono out of green fabric.
examples.ja: 緑色の布地を使って着物を作りました。

examples.en: I fell in love with a textile at the fabric store today, but it was too expensive for me to buy.
examples.ja: 今日生地屋さんで一目ぼれした布地があったんだけど、高すぎて買えなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Cloth</kanji> from the <kanji>earth</kanji> is still <vocabulary>cloth</vocabulary>, just a little dirty.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, you've learned them both already!

examples.en: I can’t eat something so strange.
examples.ja: こんな得体の知れないもの、食べられないよ。

examples.en: I thought a mysterious man was looking at me, but it turned out to be Koichi from Tofugu.
examples.ja: 得体の知れない男がさっきからこっちを見ていると思ったら、トーフグのコウイチだった。

examples.en: I suddenly felt as if something unidentifiable was coming towards me at furious speeds and I started sweating with fear.
examples.ja: 得体の知れない何かが、猛スピードで迫ってくるような感覚に襲われ、冷や汗が止まらなくなりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
With time your <kanji>body</kanji> will <kanji>acquire</kanji> a certain type of <vocabulary>character</vocabulary>. It shows your true <vocabulary>nature</vocabulary> as a person.

Note: We almost always use this word in the phrases 得体が知れない/得体の知れない, so check out the context sentences to see what kind of "character" we're talking about.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

examples.en: Do you have any tips for studying Japanese?
examples.ja: 日本語を勉強する際の心得のようなものはありますか？

examples.en: "If I remember correctly, Kanae-chan should have some knowledge of French," said Mami with a knowing look.
examples.ja: 「確か、カナエちゃんは多少フランス語の心得があったはずですよ。」と、マミが心得顔で言いました。

examples.en: My senpai passed on his knowledge about job hunting.
examples.ja: 先輩が就職活動の心得を教えてくれました。

meaning_mnemonic:
What does your <kanji>heart</kanji> want to <kanji>acquire</kanji> above all other things? <vocabulary>Knowledge</vocabulary>! That's why you're here, isn't it? 

Dig deep and see that all your heart wants is more <vocabulary>tips</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rules</vocabulary>, to gain a better <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary> of… Japanese!

心得 refers to practical skills or knowledge gained through learning, like expertise in tea ceremony or mastery of a foreign language. It can also mean things to keep in mind in certain situations, like phone etiquette or know-how for a job.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I use this lifehack in the morning so I can wake up properly.
examples.ja: このライフハックを使うと、朝、すっきり目覚めることができます。

examples.en: It seems that Ken has finally become conscious of his responsibilities as a company president.
examples.ja: ケンはやっと社長としての責任感に目覚めたようだね。

examples.en: To save energy, I set the temperature of the air conditioner to 30℃, so when I woke up, I was drenched.
examples.ja: 省エネのため冷房の温度を三十度に設定しているせいで、目覚めたら汗だくになっていました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If your <kanji>eye</kanji>s are <kanji>awake</kanji> then you're going <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary>. Your eyes are usually the first thing to awaken when you're waking up, you know? 

This word can also mean <vocabulary>to awaken</vocabulary> but it's like when you to come to your senses, not literally waking up.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven’t learned this reading for 覚 yet, and in this case it also gets rendaku’d, so bear that in mind. Anyway, here’s a mnemonic to help you:

If you start <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary> in the middle of the night, it’s because of the C<reading>za</reading>r (ざ) you met that had banned sitting. This cruel, ruthless Czar keeps appearing in your nightmares, causing you to wake up incessantly. Terrifying.

examples.en: You can have the best qualifications and still lose the ability to make a living.
examples.ja: 一流の資格を持っていたって、食いっぱぐれることはあるさ。

examples.en: After the qualifying exam, let's have a party to celebrate.
examples.ja: 資格試験が終わったら、打ち上げしましょう。

examples.en: Wait, so does that mean you are entitled to receive pensions in both Japan and the U.S.?
examples.ja: じゃあ、日本とアメリカ両方で、年金の受給資格があるってことですか？

meaning_mnemonic: The credible <kanji>resources</kanji> that determine your professional <kanji>status</kanji> are your <vocabulary>qualifications</vocabulary>. You need some good ones if you want to get into a good school or land a sweet job.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Koichi is a man the world envies.
examples.ja: コウイチは、世界が羨む男だ。

examples.en: People have the tendency to envy others' happiness.
examples.ja: 人は他人の幸せを羨みがちだ。

examples.en: One day, I want to acquire wealth and fame that anyone would envy.
examples.ja: いつか誰もが羨む名声と富を手に入れたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>envy</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to envy</vocabulary> someone.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're really starting <vocabulary>to envy</vocabulary> those <reading>ura</reading>nium <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (うらや). That's the new Yankees team hopped up on uranium that were created in a lab. Even though they're gross and hulk-ish, they're really good at baseball, so you're jealous of them.

examples.en: Hachi is a target of jealousy in the dog world.
examples.ja: ハチは、犬界での羨望の的だ。

examples.en: He was eating such delicious-looking curry bread that he attracted envious stares.
examples.ja: 彼は、あまりにも美味しそうなカレーパンを食べていたため羨望の視線を浴びた。

examples.en: I couldn't ignore my envious feelings toward Gordon and I decided to pursue my career in cuisine.
examples.ja: ゴードンへの羨望の気持ちが抑えきれず、料理の道へ進みました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Envy</kanji> consumes your <kanji>hope</kanji> turning it all to <vocabulary>envy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jealousy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: That person is always irritated, huh?
examples.ja: あの人、いつも苛々しているね。

examples.en: Don't get impatient while you're driving.
examples.ja: 運転しながら苛々しないでよ。

examples.en: It's not like I’m trying to get annoyed.
examples.ja: 私だって苛々したくてしてる訳じゃないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Double <kanji>frustration</kanji> would cause anyone <vocabulary>to get irritated</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to get annoyed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to grow impatient</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This isn’t the reading you learned with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don’t just get irritated, you get <reading>ira-ira</reading>-tated (いらいら). That's the next level up from irritated.

This word is often written in katakana or hiragana, but you'll sometimes see it in kanji too, so it's worth knowing!

examples.en: Drunk driving is a crime.
examples.ja: 飲酒運転は犯罪です。

examples.en: I don't want to drink and drive, so I'll go home by taxi.
examples.ja: 飲酒運転はしたくないから、タクシーで帰るよ。

examples.en: I didn't know it was considered drunk driving with a bicycle, but that makes sense.
examples.ja: 自転車でも飲酒運転とみなされるとは知りませんでしたが、なるほどと思いました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 飲酒 is "drinking alcohol" and 運転する is "to drive", so it makes sense that this word means <vocabulary>drunk driving</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>drinking and driving</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I wish I could get rid of my American accent in Japanese.
examples.ja: 日本語のアメリカなまりを無くしたいな。

examples.en: The most important thing is to do away with stress.
examples.ja: 何よりもストレスを無くすことが大切です。

examples.en: What do you think caused you to lose your self-confidence?
examples.ja: ご自身が自信を無くした原因は何だと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word ends with a う sound so you can guess it's a verb. The kanji means <kanji>nothing</kanji>, and you'll end up with nothing if you want to <vocabulary>to get rid of something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to do away with something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose something</vocabulary>.

This verb is transitive, so the action is happening to something. So maybe you're getting rid of debt, or discrimination, or stress... Whatever it is, there's a direct object with this verb!
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you already learned when you learned the word 無し.

examples.en: Adults work and receive money, right?
examples.ja: 大人は仕事をしてお金を貰うんでしょ？

examples.en: I received a necklace as a gift.
examples.ja: プレゼントにネックレスを貰いました。

examples.en: I always get energy from your smile.
examples.ja: あなたの笑顔にはいつも元気を貰います。

examples.en: Could I receive some advice about this?
examples.ja: これについてアドバイスを貰えませんか？

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>receive</kanji>, making this <vocabulary>to receive something</vocabulary>, or alternatively, <vocabulary>to get something from someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be given something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: Walking away without saying a word is not cool.
examples.ja: 何も言わずに立ち去るなんて、ひどいよ。

examples.en: Leave this place now, quickly!
examples.ja: 早くここから立ち去れ！

examples.en: The man quickly left the spot.
examples.ja: 男はその場を足早に立ち去った。

meaning_mnemonic:
You 立つ and then 去る. Makes sense, as in order <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>, you'll have to stand up first.

立ち去る describes the physical act of leaving a place, often used when walking away from a scene or departing a place after some kind of incident or event.
reading_mnemonic: This combines the readings of two verbs you already know, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: I hope this wish comes true someday.
examples.ja: いつかこの願いが叶うといいな。

examples.en: Anyway, it was a love that was never meant to be.
examples.ja: どうせ、叶わぬ恋だったんだよ。

examples.en: Don't worry, if you don't give up, your dreams will surely come true!
examples.ja: 大丈夫、あきらめなければ、夢はきっと叶うよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>come true</kanji>, and this is the intransitive verb version of that, making this <vocabulary>to come true</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be fulfilled</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a verb, so it uses the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you already learned this with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

examples.en: They say it's the season of harvest in autumn, don't they?
examples.ja: 実りの秋っていいますもんね。

examples.en: Autumn is the season of harvest, so there are lots of delicious things.
examples.ja: 秋は実りの季節ですから、美味しいものがたくさんあります。

examples.en: Thanks to everyone, it turned out to be a very fruitful workshop.
examples.ja: 皆さんのおかげで、とても実り多い研究会になりました。

examples.en: I believe that studying abroad always brings significant rewards.
examples.ja: 海外に出て学ぶことは、必ず大きな実りをもたらすと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 実る means "to bear fruit"? This is just the noun version of that word, so it means <vocabulary>harvest</vocabulary>. (A nice harvest is what you get when your crops literally bear fruit!)

Literally speaking, 実り refers to fruit and crops that are ripe and ready to be harvested. It's a bit old-fashioned and poetic, but you might see it in phrases like 実りの秋 (the fruitful season of autumn). Like the verb version 実る, it's more often used figuratively nowadays to refer to the <vocabulary>fruits</vocabulary> of hard work.
reading_mnemonic: This is just the noun version of the verb 実る, which you've already learned how to read, so you should be good to go here!
